problem.prob_desc:
28. 그림과 같이 서로 다른 두 평면 $\alpha,\ \beta$의 교선 위에 $\overline{\mathrm{AB}}=18$인 두 점 $\mathrm{A,\ B}$가 있다. 선분 $\mathrm{AB}$를 지름으로 하는 원 $C_1$이 평면 $\alpha$ 위에 있고, 선분 $\mathrm{AB}$를 장축으로 하고 두 점 $\mathrm{F,\ F'}$을 초점으로 하는 타원 $C_2$가 평면 $\beta$ 위에 있다. 원 $C_1$ 위의 한 점 $\mathrm{P}$에서 평면 $\beta$에 내린 수선의 발을 $\mathrm{H}$라 할 때, $\overline{\mathrm{HF'}} \lt \overline{\mathrm{HF'}}$이고 $\angle{\mathrm{HFF'}}=\dfrac{\pi}{6}$이다. 직선 $\mathrm{HF}$와 타원 $C_2$가 만나는 점 중 점 $\mathrm{H}$와 가까운 점을 $\mathrm{Q}$라 하면, $\overline{\mathrm{FH}} \lt \overline{\mathrm{FQ}}$이다. 점 $\mathrm{H}$를 중심으로 하고 점 $\mathrm{Q}$를 지나는 평면 $\beta$ 위의 원은 반지름의 길이가 4이고 직선 $\mathrm{AB}$에 접한다. 두 평면 $\alpha,\ \beta$가 이루는 각의 크기를 $\theta$라 할 때, $\cos\theta$의 값은? (단, 점 $\mathrm{P}$는 평면 $\beta$ 위에 있지 않다.) [4점]
① $\dfrac{2\sqrt{66}}{33}$ ② $\dfrac{4\sqrt{69}}{69}$ ③ $\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{3}$ ④ $\dfrac{4\sqrt{3}}{15}$ ⑤ $\dfrac{2\sqrt{78}}{39}$

gpt-5-codex.title: Coordinate setup
gpt-5-codex.body: Let plane β be the xy-plane with AB as the x-axis, so A(-9,0,0), B(9,0,0), and the ellipse has center O(0,0,0) with foci F(c,0,0), F′(-c,0,0). Plane α is obtained by rotating β about the x-axis by θ, so any point P on circle C₁ (radius 9) has coordinates P=(x, y cosθ, −y sinθ) with x² + y² = 81. The foot H of the perpendicular from P to β is H=(x, y cosθ, 0). Because the circle in β centered at H tangent to AB (the x-axis) through Q has radius 4, the distance from H to the x-axis is 4, giving y cosθ = 4.

gpt-5-codex.title: Use angle condition
gpt-5-codex.body: Vector FH = (x−c, 4) and F′F = (−2c, 0). The angle ∠HFF′ = π/6 implies (−2c)(x−c) / (2c·|FH|) = √3/2, so (c−x)/|FH| = √3/2. Hence |FH| = (2/√3)(c−x). Also |FH|² = (c−x)² + 16, leading to (c−x)² + 16 = (4/3)(c−x)², so (c−x)² = 48. Taking the positive root (since x < c) gives c − x = 4√3 and thus |FH| = 8.

gpt-5-codex.title: Locate Q and find c
gpt-5-codex.body: The unit vector from H to F is u = (√3/2, −1/2). Points at distance 4 from H on line HF are H ± 4u. Because FH = 8 < FQ, Q must be opposite F relative to H, so Q = H − 4u = (x − 2√3, 6). With c − x = 4√3 we have FQ = √((x−2√3−c)² + 6²) = √((−6√3)² + 36) = 12. The ellipse condition gives FQ + F′Q = 18, so F′Q = 6. Then √((x−2√3 + c)² + 36) = 6, which yields 2c − 6√3 = 0 and hence c = 3√3. Consequently x = c − 4√3 = −√3.

gpt-5-codex.title: Compute cosθ
gpt-5-codex.body: From x² + y² = 81 and x = −√3, we find y² = 81 − 3 = 78, so y = √78 (>0 because y cosθ = 4 > 0). Using y cosθ = 4 gives cosθ = 4/√78 = (2√78)/39. This matches choice ⑤.

gpt-5.title: Set coordinates and parameters
gpt-5.body: Work in plane β as z=0. Let AB be the x-axis with center O at (0,0). Then ellipse C2: x^2/81 + y^2/b^2 = 1 with a=9, b unknown, foci F=(c,0), F'=(-c,0), where c^2 = 81 - b^2. The circle in β centered at H through Q has radius 4 and is tangent to AB, so H has y-coordinate 4: H=(h,4).

gpt-5.title: Use angle at F to locate H and Q
gpt-5.body: Given ∠HFF' = π/6, the line FH makes a 150° angle with the +x-axis, so its slope is m = -tan 30° = -1/√3. Thus (4 - 0)/(h - c) = -1/√3 ⇒ h - c = -4√3 ⇒ H=(c - 4√3, 4). The line through F has parametric form (x,y) = (c,0) + t(1, m). The distance scale along this line is √(1+m^2) = 2/√3. The nearer intersection Q with the ellipse and FH satisfies HQ = 4 and FH < FQ. With m<0 and y(H)=4, we get t_H = -4√3; the two points at distance 4 from H on this line are t = t_H ± 2√3. The condition FH < FQ selects t_Q = -6√3, giving Q = (c - 6√3, 6).

gpt-5.title: Determine the ellipse’s focus c
gpt-5.body: Since Q lies on C2, (c - 6√3)^2/81 + 36/b^2 = 1 with c^2 = 81 - b^2. Eliminating b^2 yields (c - 6√3)^2/81 + 36/(81 - c^2) = 1. This simplifies to the quartic (in s=c): s^4 - 12√3 s^3 - 54 s^2 + 972√3 s - 5103 = 0, which factors as (s^2 - 6√3 s + 27)(s^2 - 6√3 s - 189) = 0. The only valid (nonnegative, ≤9) root is c = 3√3, hence b^2 = 81 - c^2 = 54.

gpt-5.title: Relate projection to angle between planes
gpt-5.body: Let plane β be z=0; plane α is obtained by rotating β about AB (x-axis) by θ. Any P on circle C1 (radius 9 in α centered at O) can be written P=(x, t cosθ, t sinθ) with x^2 + t^2 = 81. Its foot on β is H=(x, t cosθ, 0). We have y(H)=4 ⇒ t cosθ = 4. From Step 1, x(H)=c - 4√3 = 3√3 - 4√3 = -√3, so x^2 = 3. Using x^2 + t^2 = 81 gives t^2 = 78. Thus cos^2 θ = (t cosθ)^2 / t^2 = 16/78 = 8/39, so cos θ = 2√78/39 (acute angle).

gpt-5.title: Select the correct option
gpt-5.body: cos θ = 2√78/39 corresponds to option ⑤.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Setup the coordinate system and basic parameters
claude-opus-4.5.body:
Place the intersection line AB along the x-axis with center at origin.
- A = (-9, 0, 0), B = (9, 0, 0) since AB = 18
- Circle C₁ in plane α has diameter AB, so radius = 9, center at origin
- Ellipse C₂ in plane β has major axis AB, so semi-major axis a = 9
- Let F and F' be foci of ellipse at (c, 0, 0) and (-c, 0, 0) in plane β

claude-opus-4.5.title: Analyze point H and the circle condition
claude-opus-4.5.body:
H is the foot of perpendicular from P (on circle C₁) to plane β.
The circle centered at H passing through Q has radius 4 and is tangent to line AB.
This means the distance from H to line AB equals 4.

Since H is in plane β and its distance to line AB is 4, if we set up coordinates in plane β with AB along x-axis, then H has y-coordinate (in plane β) equal to 4.

So HQ = 4 (radius of circle through Q centered at H).

claude-opus-4.5.title: Use angle condition to find relationship
claude-opus-4.5.body:
Given: ∠HFF' = π/6 and HF' > HF (correcting the typo in problem)
F is at (c, 0) and F' is at (-c, 0) in plane β coordinates.

Let H = (h, 4) in plane β coordinates (distance 4 from AB).
Since ∠HFF' = π/6 and the angle is at F looking toward F':
tan(π/6) = 4/(h - c) = 1/√3
So h - c = 4√3, meaning h = c + 4√3

claude-opus-4.5.title: Find FH and use ellipse properties
claude-opus-4.5.body:
FH = √[(h-c)² + 16] = √[(4√3)² + 16] = √[48 + 16] = √64 = 8

Q is on line HF and on ellipse C₂, with FQ > FH (H is closer to Q than F is).
Wait, the problem says FH < FQ, so Q is beyond H from F.

Actually, Q is the intersection point closer to H, and FH < FQ means H is between F and Q.
So HQ = FQ - FH.

Since circle through Q has radius 4: HQ = 4
Therefore FQ = FH + HQ = 8 + 4 = 12

claude-opus-4.5.title: Apply ellipse focal chord property
claude-opus-4.5.body:
For point Q on ellipse: QF + QF' = 2a = 18
So QF' = 18 - FQ = 18 - 12 = 6

Using the focal chord formula for ellipse:
For a point at distance r from focus F along a line making angle θ with major axis:
r = b²/a / (1 - e·cos(angle from focus))

The line HF makes angle π/6 with FF' (measured at F toward F').
Actually, the angle from the major axis = π - π/6 = 5π/6 (since H is above the axis and angle HFF' = π/6)

claude-opus-4.5.title: Use focal radius formula
claude-opus-4.5.body:
For ellipse, focal radius: r = a(1-e²)/(1 + e·cos(φ)) where φ is angle from focus
Here FQ = 12, and the angle from F toward the direction of Q (away from F') is π - π/6 = 5π/6

12 = (a·b²/a²)/(1 + e·cos(5π/6)) = b²/a / (1 - e·(√3/2))
12 = b²/(a(1 - e√3/2))

Also b² = a² - c² = 81 - c², and e = c/9
12 = (81 - c²)/(9(1 - c√3/18)) = (81 - c²)/(9 - c√3/2)

12(9 - c√3/2) = 81 - c²
108 - 6c√3 = 81 - c²
c² - 6√3c + 27 = 0
c = (6√3 ± √(108-108))/2 = 3√3

claude-opus-4.5.title: Calculate cos θ using projection
claude-opus-4.5.body:
c = 3√3, so b² = 81 - 27 = 54, b = 3√6

H = (c + 4√3, 4) = (3√3 + 4√3, 4) = (7√3, 4) in plane β

P is on circle C₁ with radius 9. P projects to H on plane β.
The x-coordinate of P equals x-coordinate of H = 7√3
P is on circle: x² + y² = 81 (in plane α)
So y²_P = 81 - (7√3)² = 81 - 147 = -66... Error!

Rechecking: The projection preserves the x-coordinate (along AB), but the perpendicular distance from P to plane β relates to the angle θ.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Correct geometric relationship
claude-opus-4.5.body:
Let P have distance d from line AB in plane α.
The projection H has distance d·cos(θ) from line AB in plane β = 4.

P is on circle C₁ with radius 9, center at origin on line AB.
Distance from P to AB = √(9² - x²_P) where x_P is the x-coordinate.

x_P = x_H = 7√3 (projection preserves x-coordinate along intersection line)
Distance of P from AB = √(81 - 147)... still negative.

Let me reconsider: h = c + 4√3 = 3√3 + 4√3 = 7√3 ≈ 12.1 > 9, impossible for projection.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Reconsider the geometry - H between foci
claude-opus-4.5.body:
If HF < HF', then H is closer to F. With ∠HFF' = π/6, H could be between the foci.
tan(π/6) = 4/(c - h) gives c - h = 4√3, so h = c - 4√3 = 3√3 - 4√3 = -√3

FH = 8 (same calculation)
H = (-√3, 4) in plane β

Now x_P = -√3, distance of P from AB = √(81 - 3) = √78
cos θ = 4/√78 = 4√78/78 = 2√78/39

gemini-3-pro.title: Set up coordinates and analyze geometry
gemini-3-pro.body: Let the intersection line of planes $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the x-axis, with the midpoint of $\overline{\mathrm{AB}}$ as the origin $(0,0)$. Thus $\mathrm{A}=(-9,0)$ and $\mathrm{B}=(9,0)$. On plane $\alpha$, circle $C_1$ has equation $x^2 + y'^2 = 9^2$. On plane $\beta$, ellipse $C_2$ has major axis $2a=18 \implies a=9$. Let the foci be $\mathrm{F}(c,0)$ and $\mathrm{F'}(-c,0)$ with $c>0$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Calculate distances FH and FQ
gemini-3-pro.body: The circle centered at $\mathrm{H}$ passing through $\mathrm{Q}$ is tangent to $\mathrm{AB}$, so the distance from $\mathrm{H}$ to the x-axis is $d(\mathrm{H}, \mathrm{AB})=4$. $\mathrm{H}=(x_H, 4)$ in $\beta$. In $\triangle\mathrm{HMF}$ (where $M$ is the projection of $\mathrm{H}$ on x-axis), $\angle\mathrm{HFF'}=30^\circ$ and $HM=4$, so $\overline{\mathrm{FH}} = \frac{4}{\sin 30^\circ} = 8$. The circle radius is $\overline{\mathrm{HQ}}=4$. Since $\overline{\mathrm{FH}} < \overline{\mathrm{FQ}}$ and $\mathrm{Q}$ lies on the line passing through $\mathrm{F, H}$, the order of points is $\mathrm{F}-\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{Q}$. Thus $\overline{\mathrm{FQ}} = \overline{\mathrm{FH}} + \overline{\mathrm{HQ}} = 8 + 4 = 12$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Determine the focus c via Cosine Rule
gemini-3-pro.body: $\mathrm{Q}$ is on the ellipse, so $\overline{\mathrm{QF}} + \overline{\mathrm{QF'}} = 2a = 18 \implies \overline{\mathrm{QF'}} = 6$. In $\triangle\mathrm{QFF'}$, $\overline{\mathrm{QF}}=12$, $\overline{\mathrm{QF'}}=6$, $\overline{\mathrm{FF'}}=2c$, and $\angle\mathrm{QFF'}=30^\circ$. By the Law of Cosines: $6^2 = 12^2 + (2c)^2 - 2(12)(2c)\cos 30^\circ$. Simplifying: $36 = 144 + 4c^2 - 24\sqrt{3}c \implies 4c^2 - 24\sqrt{3}c + 108 = 0 \implies c^2 - 6\sqrt{3}c + 27 = 0$. Solving gives $(c-3\sqrt{3})^2=0$, so $c=3\sqrt{3}$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Find coordinates of point H
gemini-3-pro.body: From $\triangle\mathrm{HMF}$, the horizontal distance $|x_H - c| = 4 \cot 30^\circ = 4\sqrt{3}$. Since $\mathrm{F}=(3\sqrt{3},0)$, $x_H$ is either $7\sqrt{3}$ or $-\sqrt{3}$. Point $\mathrm{P}$ is on circle $x^2+y'^2=81$, so $|x_H| \le 9$. $7\sqrt{3} > 9$ is invalid, so $x_H = -\sqrt{3}$. Thus $\mathrm{H}=(-\sqrt{3}, 4)$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Calculate cos(θ)
gemini-3-pro.body: Point $\mathrm{P}$ on plane $\alpha$ has x-coordinate $-\sqrt{3}$. Substituting into $x^2 + y'^2 = 81$: $(-\sqrt{3})^2 + y'^2 = 81 \implies y'^2 = 78 \implies |y'| = \sqrt{78}$. $\mathrm{H}$ is the projection of $\mathrm{P}$ onto $\beta$, so the y-coordinate on $\beta$, $y_H=4$, relates to $y'$ by $y_H = |y'| \cos \theta$. Thus, $4 = \sqrt{78} \cos \theta \implies \cos \theta = \frac{4}{\sqrt{78}} = \frac{4\sqrt{78}}{78} = \frac{2\sqrt{78}}{39}$.

grok-4-fast.title: Set up coordinates and planes
grok-4-fast.body: Place the intersection line AB along the x-axis with A at (-9,0,0) and B at (9,0,0). Define plane α as z=0 (xy-plane). Define plane β with equation y sin θ + z cos θ = 0, so z = -y tan θ. The normal to β is (0, sin θ, cos θ), ensuring the dihedral angle is θ. Circle C1 in α: x² + y² = 81, z=0. Point P = (x_p, y_p, 0) with x_p² + y_p² = 81, assume y_p > 0.

grok-4-fast.title: Find foot H from P to β
grok-4-fast.body: The perpendicular from P to β uses direction (0, sin θ, cos θ). Parametric line: (x_p, y_p + t sin θ, t cos θ). Intersection with β gives t = -y_p sin θ. Thus, H = (x_p, y_p cos² θ, -y_p sin θ cos θ).

grok-4-fast.title: Distance from H to AB is 4
grok-4-fast.body: Distance from H to x-axis: √(y_h² + z_h²) = |y_p cos θ| = 4. With y_p > 0 and cos θ > 0, y_p cos θ = 4, so y_p = 4 / cos θ.

grok-4-fast.title: Ellipse C2 and foci
grok-4-fast.body: Ellipse in β with major axis AB=18, so a=9, foci F=(-c,0,0), F'=(c,0,0), c = 9e. In β coordinates (s, t): point (s, t cos θ, -t sin θ), ellipse (s/9)² + (t/b)² = 1, b² = 81 - c². H: s_h = x_p, t_h = 4.

grok-4-fast.title: Angle ∠HFF' = π/6
grok-4-fast.body: Vector FH = (x_p + c, y_p cos² θ, -y_p sin θ cos θ), FF' = (2c, 0, 0). Cos(π/6) = √3/2 = (x_p + c) / HF. Also, HF² = (x_p + c)² + 16 = 64, HF=8. Thus, x_p + c = 4√3, x_p = 4√3 - c.

grok-4-fast.title: Parametrize line HF and find Q
grok-4-fast.body: In (s,t): parametric σ from H: s = x_p - σ (x_p + c), t = 4(1 - σ), k = x_p + c = 4√3. Direction length 8, so distance from H is 8|σ|. HQ=4 implies |σ_Q| = 1/2. For FH < FQ and Q closer to H, σ_Q = -1/2 (opposite side). Then s_Q = x_p + (1/2)k = (3/2)k - c = 6√3 - c, t_Q = 6.

grok-4-fast.title: Find cos θ from circle condition
grok-4-fast.body: x_p = √3, y_p = 4 / cos θ. Then (√3)² + (4 / cos θ)² = 81 → 16 / cos² θ = 78 → cos² θ = 16/78 = 8/39 → cos θ = √(8/39) = 2√78 / 39 (matches option ⑤).
